_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Seismic inspection of tanks, pumps, vaporizers, piping, supports, etc.
_prev_prog_2.Description: Aqueous Ammonia for Control of NOx Emissions

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

Modesto Irrigation District (MID) is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the Woodland Generation Station (WGS).  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the aqueous ammonia process.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  MID has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the process equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at WGS.    



In addition, MID has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), which details the response WGS will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of aqueous ammonia.  The EAP includes procedures for evacuating personnel from the area where the emergency is located and notifying local emergency responders.  The EAP is maintained current and updated periodically.



MID has coordinated with local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the aqueous ammonia process and with the general safety and accidental release program at WGS.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

MID operates WGS, which generates electric power provided to customers in the surrounding area.  WGS is located at 1240 Graphics Avenue in Modesto, Stanislaus County, California.  The facility is situated on the southeast corner of Woodland Avenue and Graphics Avenue, approximately 0.2 miles east of Highway 99.  The property is surrounded by industrial facilities and commercial businesses to the east, north, and west, and vacant land to the south. 



WGS is equipped with two gas turbine engine powered generators (referred to as WGS Units 1 and 2), six internal combustion reciprocating engine powered electrical generators (referred to as WGS Unit 3), and associated eq

uipment. All eight engines are fueled by natural gas.

  

Aqueous Ammonia (29% solution) is the regulated substance maintained at WGS.  The chemical is stored in an aboveground storage tank.  The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia stored at a given time is 12,600 gallons (94,500 pounds) of solution.  At 29% concentration, the mixture contains approximately 27,400 pounds of ammonia, which exceeds the EPA Risk Management Program threshold of 20,000 pounds for concentrations 20 percent or greater and the CalARP Program threshold of 500 pounds of ammonia in solution; therefore, this process is subject to the EPA Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations. The aqueous ammonia process at WGS qualifies for Program Level 2.



Aqueous ammonia is used at the WGS in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control emissions of NOx from natural gas combustion. Aqueous ammonia is vaporized and injected into the exhaust gas stream from WGS Units 1 and 2 and then passed through a catalyst bed. At WGS Unit 3, however, aqueous ammonia is sprayed into the exhaust stream in liquid form and is vaporized and mixed directly in the exhaust before entering the SCR grid. In the presence of the catalyst, the ammonia and NOx react to form nitrogen and water vapor, thereby reducing NOx emissions.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

MID has developed a RMP/CalARP Program for the aqueous ammonia process. The program includes but is not limited to the following elements:

?    Safety Information that describes the hazards of aqueous ammonia and the process in which aqueous ammonia is used.  This includes the chemical safety data sheet, process description, operating limits, equipment specifications, and the codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the process.

?    Hazard Review to identify the hazards associated with the aqueous ammonia process and to evaluate the engineering and administrative safeguards in place to eliminate or reduce those hazards.

?    Oper

ating Procedures, comprised of clear, written instructions to operate the system.  This includes several phases of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, startup following an emergency shutdown, and equipment inspections.

?    Training Program for employees involved with operating and maintaining the process to ensure they understand the chemical and process hazards and the procedures they are required to perform as part of their job duties.

?    Maintenance Program for the continued integrity of the process equipment and associated safety systems.  This addresses equipment testing and inspections, preventative maintenance schedules, personnel training, and correction of equipment deficiencies.

?    Compliance Audits of the RMP/CalARP Program to ensure compliance with EPA and CalARP regulations and to evaluate MID's ability to effectively implement the program.  

?    Incident Investigations for investigating a chemical release or a near miss. This includes identifying the cause of the incident and any contributing factors and implementing measures to prevent recurrence.



Five Year Accident History

A review of the facility's five-year accident history showed that there have been no incidents onsite that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no releases of aqueous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity.



Emergency Response Program

MID has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) addressing chemical releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and outside emergency response person

nel, and 4) administering first aid measures for chemical exposure.  Employees are trained on the EAP procedures initially upon hire and receive annual refresher training.



In the event of an aqueous ammonia release, the highest-ranking WGS operations person onsite will assess whether the release is controllable (i.e., incidental and easily controlled) or uncontrollable. If the release is controllable, trained WGS personnel will perform the tasks necessary to accomplish containment and mitigation of the release. If the release is uncontrollable, the MID Control Center will notify the Modesto Fire Department. The Modesto Fire Department will handle spill/release response and mitigation.



The Emergency Action Plan is shared with the Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources through the annual submission of the Hazardous Materials Business Plan. MID also works closely with the Modesto Fire Department to coordinate response actions inviting fire department staff to tour WGS and the aqueous ammonia system. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Hazard Reviews and Compliance Audits have been performed on the aqueous ammonia process, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at WGS.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  MID has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.  In addition, MID plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures and conducting reviews and audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
